newsitem.title: USA: U.S. June spot natgas prices soften from indices.
newsitem.headline: U.S. June spot natgas prices soften from indices.

text.p: U.S. spot natural gas prices extended their losses Friday as next-day and June swing prices were for the most part in convergence, industry sources said.
June Louisiana Gulf Coast prices were talked notionally five to six cents lower in the low-$2.20s, still up about 10 cents from May indices.

Weighing on the cash market were additional losses in the futures market and cool, overcast weather throughout most of the U.S., traders said. NYMEX's July Henry Hub contract slid to a low of $2.20, down five cents from Thursday's session.
For weekend delivery, Gulf prices were also lower in the low-$2.20s.

In south Texas, June prices were quoted in the mid-teens, down about three to four cents from Thursday. Temperatures in Houston are expected to reach highs in the mid-to-high 80s F this weekend, Weather Services Corp said.
In the Midwest, where temperatures remain below normal, June prices softened by about five cents to about $2.04-2.07, indicating a jump of about 10 cents from May index levels.
Temperatures in Chicago were forecast to reach highs in mid-70s Saturday and high-60s Sunday, according to WSC said.
In the East, New York city gate June prices were quoted in the mid-$2.40s, while Appalachian prices eased into the high-$2.30s.

In the West, Permian prices slipped three cents to about $2.05 as rains pushed temperatures closer to normal in southern California. In Los Angeles, forecasters called for highs in the low-80s this weekend, a drop of about 10 degrees F.
The 1,221 megawatt (MW) Palo Verde 1 nuclear unit, shut late Monday for repairs, was expected to be back on line Friday.
Meanwhile, Pacific Gas and Electric's 1,087 MW Diablo Canyon 1 nuclear unit is expected to restart this weekend following its refueling outage.
